abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated
            satisfactory and the project benefits are assessed as likely
            to be sustained. Both World Bank and Borrower performances
            were adjudged as satisfactory overall. The project was the
            first stand alone dam safety project financed by the Bank,
            and as such, the lessons emerging are of particular
            interest. The main lesson is that in circumstances with new
            ideas and institutions, realism is needed in design and
            planning, and adequate time is required for implementation.
            Either the preparation phase or the time allowed for the
            implementation should have been different here. The project
            and the processes used in this intensive learning ICR have
            also highlighted a great many technical issues in design,
            implementation, institutional development, and coordination.
            These are as follows: Highly technical components, such as
            flood forecasting using telemetry and risk analysis must be
            thoroughly prepared before appraisal, using international
            consultants. The supply and installation contract should
            include an on-the-job training component. The project design
            should include developing computer systems to analyze storm
            data. Training for engineers in dam safety should be
            institutionalized. Dam investments must be prioritized
            according to appropriate risk analysis. Dam safety review
            panels should be constituted to ensure quick and sensible
            decisionmaking. Clearer rules of operation and an urgent
            need for reviewing spillway capacities are among other issues.
